ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: You focus on close reading. What broader themes or questions are prompted by the examination of a particular word or phrase? Professor Brisman recommends an approach to writing English essays that I hadn't come across before. You pose a problem in the introduction, and spend your essay weighing up the alternative 'solutions' or interpretations that shed light on your problem. Professor Brisman would be disgruntled if I did not say that you learn a lot about life in this course. He helps us see poetry as a way of gaining wisdom or a new perspective that changes how we lead our life.
Great introduction to Modern poetry facilitated through introspective and philosophical discussions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The professor was great. A clear passion for the subject matter that is infectious for all students.

I learned more from this course than any course I've done at Yale. Each class was a kind of revelation! The questions that Professor Brisman poses in class open up a really exciting class discussion. You see the poems in a completely new way. You learn which questions the reader should ask when approaching a new poem. The class is also really well structured. Professor Brisman begins each class with what he considers the most important matter, and every class is framed around the 'epigraph' that he writes on the board. We often dealt with two poets at once, switching back and forth between the two poets in class. There is a focus on close reading throughout, which was new to me -- and very illuminating!

Strengths: Great reading assignments, knowledgeable and enthusiastic professor

Weaknesses: Too many writing assignments (5 rather than 3 like in other English Poetry Sections), sometimes discussions were unorganized and abstract

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course. The class discussions are riveting, and Professor Brisman's questions in class stir you to see the poems in new ways and with layers of meaning that escaped you upon first reading! It's true that the Professor is a harsher grader than most teachers I've encountered, and you have to write five essays as opposed to three in most of the other ENGL 126 courses. But the workload is totally worth it! You learn how to dally between alternative interpretations of the same poem, how to closely read a single line or word, and how to view poetry as a guide to living a fuller life.

I would recommend this course depending on the type of class you want to take. It you are interested in philosophical and abstract conversations, this is a great class and Professor Brisman is very enthusiastic and knowledgeable. However, if you are seeking more structured or conventional conversations, another Engl 126 class might be a better alternative.
